title: Michael van Gerwen 'always tries to get under my skin,' says Dave Chisnall
text:
Dave Chisnall lost out in the World Grand Prix final on Saturday (Picture: Lawrence Lustig)

Dave Chisnall says Michael van Gerwen is always trying to ‘get under his skin’ after losing the World Grand Prix final to the Dutchman on Saturday night.

MVG claimed his fifth Grand Prix title with a 5-2 win over Chizzy in Dublin, retaining the trophy for the first time in his illustrious career.

Chisnall was appearing in his second Grand Prix final after losing 6-0 to Phil Taylor in 2013, and put up an impressive fight against the world number one.

The game was level at 1-1 and the third and fourth sets were both narrowly won 3-2 by Van Gerwen, which gave him a commanding lead in a contest that was actually very tight.

Mighty Mike displayed plenty of passion on the stage at the Citywest Hotel and when asked by Live Darts if Chisnall thought MVG was trying to get under his skin with his vocal outbursts, the Englishman agreed.

‘That’s Michael van Gerwen, he always tries to get under my skin, but I didn’t let him tonight,’ said Chizzy.

‘I was the calmest person on that stage tonight and he was getting bothered, but he still throws the darts.’

Chisnall goes away from the tournament satisfied after reaching his first major final since 2016, although he is still searching for his first major title, having now fallen short in five finals.

The Englishman has not had it easy on the biggest stages in darts, losing out to Phil Taylor at the Grand Prix and Grand Slam, before losing a hat-trick of finals to Van Gerwen at the Masters, Players Championship Finals and now at the Grand Prix.

‘It’s been up all week till that last 20 seconds on stage,’ continued Chisnall. ‘I played well, I missed a few opportunities up there and he took his, it’s fine margins.

‘When you go 4-1 in sets down to Michael van Gerwen its always going to be tough, but I never give in, I battled through it.

‘I’ve had a great tournament and I’m very happy. I’ve got to the final and I’ll probably get to more finals if I play like that.

‘It was a game of fine margins and I missed crucial doubles in a couple of legs, but that’s darts. He punished me and it’s my own fault, but I will work on it.

‘I’ve had a great tournament and the atmosphere during the final was fantastic, the crowd gave us both great support. I did better than in 2013 and I’m proud of myself.’
